segment.source: Creating the DaRT 10 Recovery Image
segment.target: Creating the DaRT 10 Recovery Image

segment.source: Creating the DaRT 10 Recovery Image
segment.target: Creating the DaRT 10 Recovery Image

segment.source: Creating the DaRT 10 Recovery Image
segment.target: Creating the DaRT 10 Recovery Image

segment.source: After installing Microsoft Diagnostics and Recovery Toolset (DaRT) 10, you create a DaRT 10 recovery image.
segment.target: After installing Microsoft Diagnostics and Recovery Toolset (DaRT) 10, you create a DaRT 10 recovery image.

segment.source: The recovery image starts Windows RE, from which you can then start the DaRT tools.
segment.target: The recovery image starts Windows RE, from which you can then start the DaRT tools.

segment.source: You can generate International Organization for Standardization (ISO) files and Windows Imaging Format (WIM) images.
segment.target: You can generate International Organization for Standardization (ISO) files and Windows Imaging Format (WIM) images.

segment.source: In addition, you can use PowerShell to generate scripts that use the settings you select in the DaRT Recovery Image wizard.
segment.target: In addition, you can use PowerShell to generate scripts that use the settings you select in the DaRT Recovery Image wizard.

segment.source: You can use the script later to rebuild recovery images by using the same settings.
segment.target: You can use the script later to rebuild recovery images by using the same settings.

segment.source: The recovery image provides a variety of recovery tools.
segment.target: The recovery image provides a variety of recovery tools.

segment.source: For a description of the tools, see Overview of the Tools in DaRT 10.
segment.target: For a description of the tools, see Overview of the Tools in DaRT 10.

segment.source: After you boot the computer into DaRT, you can run the different DaRT tools to try to diagnose and repair the computer.
segment.target: After you boot the computer into DaRT, you can run the different DaRT tools to try to diagnose and repair the computer.

segment.source: This section walks you through the process of creating the DaRT recovery image and lets you select the tools and features that you want to include as part of the image.
segment.target: This section walks you through the process of creating the DaRT recovery image and lets you select the tools and features that you want to include as part of the image.

segment.source: You can create the DaRT recovery image by using either of two methods:
segment.target: You can create the DaRT recovery image by using either of two methods:

segment.source: Use the DaRT Recovery Image wizard, which runs in a Windows environment.
segment.target: Use the DaRT Recovery Image wizard, which runs in a Windows environment.

segment.source: Modify an example PowerShell script with the values you want.
segment.target: Modify an example PowerShell script with the values you want.

segment.source: For more information, see How to Use a PowerShell Script to Create the Recovery Image.
segment.target: For more information, see How to Use a PowerShell Script to Create the Recovery Image.

segment.source: You can write the ISO to a recordable CD or DVD, save it to a USB flash drive, or save it in a format that you can use to boot into DaRT from a remote partition or from a recovery partition.
segment.target: You can write the ISO to a recordable CD or DVD, save it to a USB flash drive, or save it in a format that you can use to boot into DaRT from a remote partition or from a recovery partition.

segment.source: Once you have created the ISO image, you can burn it onto a blank CD or DVD (if your computer has a CD or DVD drive).
segment.target: Once you have created the ISO image, you can burn it onto a blank CD or DVD (if your computer has a CD or DVD drive).

segment.source: If your computer does not have a drive for this purpose, you can use most generic programs that are used to burn CDs or DVDs.
segment.target: If your computer does not have a drive for this purpose, you can use most generic programs that are used to burn CDs or DVDs.

segment.source: Select the image architecture and specify the path
segment.target: Select the image architecture and specify the path

segment.source: On the Windows 10 Media page, you select whether to create a 32-bit or 64-bit DaRT recovery image.
segment.target: On the Windows 10 Media page, you select whether to create a 32-bit or 64-bit DaRT recovery image.

segment.source: Use the 32-bit Windows to build 32-bit DaRT recovery images, and 64-bit Windows to build 64-bit DaRT recovery images.
segment.target: Use the 32-bit Windows to build 32-bit DaRT recovery images, and 64-bit Windows to build 64-bit DaRT recovery images.

segment.source: You can use a single computer to create recovery images for both architecture types, but you cannot create one image that works on both 32-bit and 64-bit architectures.
segment.target: You can use a single computer to create recovery images for both architecture types, but you cannot create one image that works on both 32-bit and 64-bit architectures.

segment.source: You also indicate the path of the Windows 10 installation media.
segment.target: You also indicate the path of the Windows 10 installation media.

segment.source: Choose the architecture that matches the one of the recovery image that you are creating.
segment.target: Choose the architecture that matches the one of the recovery image that you are creating.

segment.source: To select the image architecture and specify the path
segment.target: To select the image architecture and specify the path

segment.source: On the Windows 10 Media page, select one of the following:
segment.target: On the Windows 10 Media page, select one of the following:

segment.source: If you are creating a recovery image for 64-bit computers, select Create x64 (64-bit) DaRT image.
segment.target: If you are creating a recovery image for 64-bit computers, select Create x64 (64-bit) DaRT image.

segment.source: If you are creating a recovery image for 32-bit computers, select Create x86 (32-bit) DaRT image.
segment.target: If you are creating a recovery image for 32-bit computers, select Create x86 (32-bit) DaRT image.

segment.source: In the Specify the root path of the Windows 10 64-bit or 32-bit install media box, type the path of the Windows 10 installation files.
segment.target: In the Specify the root path of the Windows 10 64-bit or 32-bit install media box, type the path of the Windows 10 installation files.

segment.source: Use a path that matches the architecture of the recovery image that you are creating.
segment.target: Use a path that matches the architecture of the recovery image that you are creating.

segment.source: Click Next.
segment.target: Click Next.

segment.source: Select the tools to include on the recovery image
segment.target: Select the tools to include on the recovery image

segment.source: On the Tools page, you can select numerous tools to include on the recovery image.
segment.target: On the Tools page, you can select numerous tools to include on the recovery image.

segment.source: These tools will be available to end users when they boot into the DaRT image.
segment.target: These tools will be available to end users when they boot into the DaRT image.

segment.source: However, if you enable remote connectivity when creating the DaRT image, all of the tools will be available when a help desk worker connects to the end user’s computer, regardless of which tools you chose to include on the image.
segment.target: However, if you enable remote connectivity when creating the DaRT image, all of the tools will be available when a help desk worker connects to the end user’s computer, regardless of which tools you chose to include on the image.

segment.source: To restrict end-user access to these tools, but still retain full access to the tools through the Remote Connection Viewer, do not select those tools on the Tools page.
segment.target: To restrict end-user access to these tools, but still retain full access to the tools through the Remote Connection Viewer, do not select those tools on the Tools page.

segment.source: End users will be able to use only Remote Connection and will be able to see, but not access, any tools that you exclude from the recovery image.
segment.target: End users will be able to use only Remote Connection and will be able to see, but not access, any tools that you exclude from the recovery image.

segment.source: To select the tools to include on the recovery image
segment.target: To select the tools to include on the recovery image

segment.source: On the Tools page, select the check box beside each tool that you want to include on the image.
segment.target: On the Tools page, select the check box beside each tool that you want to include on the image.

segment.source: Click Next.
segment.target: Click Next.

segment.source: Choose whether to allow remote connectivity by a help desk
segment.target: Choose whether to allow remote connectivity by a help desk

segment.source: On the Remote Connection page, you can choose to enable a help desk worker to remotely connect to and run the DaRT tools on an end user’s computer.
segment.target: On the Remote Connection page, you can choose to enable a help desk worker to remotely connect to and run the DaRT tools on an end user’s computer.

segment.source: The remote connectivity option is then shown as an available option in the Diagnostics and Recovery Toolset window.
segment.target: The remote connectivity option is then shown as an available option in the Diagnostics and Recovery Toolset window.

segment.source: After help desk workers establish a remote connection, they can run the DaRT tools on the end-user computer from a remote location.
segment.target: After help desk workers establish a remote connection, they can run the DaRT tools on the end-user computer from a remote location.

segment.source: To choose whether to allow remote connectivity by help desk workers
segment.target: To choose whether to allow remote connectivity by help desk workers

segment.source: On the Remote Connection page, select the Allow remote connections check box to allow remote connections, or clear the check box to prevent remote connections.
segment.target: On the Remote Connection page, select the Allow remote connections check box to allow remote connections, or clear the check box to prevent remote connections.

segment.source: If you cleared the Allow remote connections check box, click Next.
segment.target: If you cleared the Allow remote connections check box, click Next.

segment.source: Otherwise, go to the next step to continue configuring remote connectivity.
segment.target: Otherwise, go to the next step to continue configuring remote connectivity.

segment.source: Select one of the following:
segment.target: Select one of the following:

segment.source: Let Windows choose an open port number.
segment.target: Let Windows choose an open port number.

segment.source: Specify the port number.
segment.target: Specify the port number.

segment.source: If you select this option, enter a port number between 1 and 65535 in the field beneath the option.
segment.target: If you select this option, enter a port number between 1 and 65535 in the field beneath the option.

segment.source: This port number will be used when establishing a remote connection.
segment.target: This port number will be used when establishing a remote connection.

segment.source: We recommend that the port number be 1024 or higher to minimize the possibility of a conflict.
segment.target: We recommend that the port number be 1024 or higher to minimize the possibility of a conflict.

segment.source: (Optional) in the Remote connection welcome message box, create a customized message that end users receive when they establish a remote connection.
segment.target: (Optional) in the Remote connection welcome message box, create a customized message that end users receive when they establish a remote connection.

segment.source: The message can be a maximum of 2048 characters.
segment.target: The message can be a maximum of 2048 characters.

segment.source: Click Next.
segment.target: Click Next.

segment.source: For more information about running the DaRT tools remotely, see How to Recover Remote Computers by Using the DaRT Recovery Image.
segment.target: For more information about running the DaRT tools remotely, see How to Recover Remote Computers by Using the DaRT Recovery Image.

segment.source: Add drivers to the recovery image
segment.target: Add drivers to the recovery image

segment.source: On the Drivers tab of the Advanced Options page, you can add additional device drivers that you may need when repairing a computer.
segment.target: On the Drivers tab of the Advanced Options page, you can add additional device drivers that you may need when repairing a computer.

segment.source: These may typically include storage or network controllers that Windows 10 does not provide.
segment.target: These may typically include storage or network controllers that Windows 10 does not provide.

segment.source: Drivers are installed when the image is created.
segment.target: Drivers are installed when the image is created.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: When you select drivers to include, be aware that wireless connectivity (such as Bluetooth or 802.11a/b/g/n) is not supported in DaRT.
segment.target: When you select drivers to include, be aware that wireless connectivity (such as Bluetooth or 802.11a/b/g/n) is not supported in DaRT.

segment.source: To add drivers to the recovery image
segment.target: To add drivers to the recovery image

segment.source: On the Advanced Options page, click the Drivers tab.
segment.target: On the Advanced Options page, click the Drivers tab.

segment.source: Click Add.
segment.target: Click Add.

segment.source: Browse to the file to be added for the driver, and then click Open.
segment.target: Browse to the file to be added for the driver, and then click Open.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The driver file is provided by the manufacturer of the storage or network controller.
segment.target: The driver file is provided by the manufacturer of the storage or network controller.

segment.source: Repeat Steps 2 and 3 for every driver that you want to include.
segment.target: Repeat Steps 2 and 3 for every driver that you want to include.

segment.source: Click Next.
segment.target: Click Next.

segment.source: Add WinPE optional packages to the recovery image
segment.target: Add WinPE optional packages to the recovery image

segment.source: On the WinPE tab of the Advanced Options page, you can add WinPE optional packages to the DaRT image.
segment.target: On the WinPE tab of the Advanced Options page, you can add WinPE optional packages to the DaRT image.

segment.source: These packages are part of the Windows ADK, which is an installation prerequisite for the DaRT Recovery Image wizard.
segment.target: These packages are part of the Windows ADK, which is an installation prerequisite for the DaRT Recovery Image wizard.

segment.source: The tools that you can select are all optional.
segment.target: The tools that you can select are all optional.

segment.source: Any required packages are added automatically, based on the tools you selected on the Tools page.
segment.target: Any required packages are added automatically, based on the tools you selected on the Tools page.

segment.source: You can also specify the size of the scratch space.
segment.target: You can also specify the size of the scratch space.

segment.source: Scratch space is the amount of RAM disk space that is set aside for DaRT to run.
segment.target: Scratch space is the amount of RAM disk space that is set aside for DaRT to run.

segment.source: The scratch space is useful in case the end user’s hard disk is not available.
segment.target: The scratch space is useful in case the end user’s hard disk is not available.

segment.source: If you are running additional tools and drivers, you may want to increase the scratch space.
segment.target: If you are running additional tools and drivers, you may want to increase the scratch space.

segment.source: To add WinPE optional packages to the recovery image
segment.target: To add WinPE optional packages to the recovery image

segment.source: On the Advanced Options page, click the WinPE tab.
segment.target: On the Advanced Options page, click the WinPE tab.

segment.source: Select the check box beside each package that you want to include on the image, or click the Name check box to select all of the packages.
segment.target: Select the check box beside each package that you want to include on the image, or click the Name check box to select all of the packages.

segment.source: In the Scratch Space field, select the amount of RAM disk space to allocate for running DaRT in case the end user’s hard disk is not available.
segment.target: In the Scratch Space field, select the amount of RAM disk space to allocate for running DaRT in case the end user’s hard disk is not available.

segment.source: Click Next.
segment.target: Click Next.

segment.source: Add the debugging tools for Crash Analyzer
segment.target: Add the debugging tools for Crash Analyzer

segment.source: If you include the Crash Analyzer tool in the ISO image, you must also include the Debugging Tools for Windows.
segment.target: If you include the Crash Analyzer tool in the ISO image, you must also include the Debugging Tools for Windows.

segment.source: On the Crash Analyzer tab of the Advanced Options page, you enter the path of the Windows 10 Debugging Tools, which Crash Analyzer uses to analyze memory dump files.
segment.target: On the Crash Analyzer tab of the Advanced Options page, you enter the path of the Windows 10 Debugging Tools, which Crash Analyzer uses to analyze memory dump files.

segment.source: You can use the tools that are on the computer where you are running the DaRT Recovery Image wizard, or you can use the tools that are on the end-user computer.
segment.target: You can use the tools that are on the computer where you are running the DaRT Recovery Image wizard, or you can use the tools that are on the end-user computer.

segment.source: If you decide to use the tools on the end-user computer, remember that every computer that you diagnose must have the Debugging Tools installed.
segment.target: If you decide to use the tools on the end-user computer, remember that every computer that you diagnose must have the Debugging Tools installed.

segment.source: If you installed the Microsoft Windows Software Development Kit (SDK) or the Microsoft Windows Development Kit (WDK), the Windows 10 Debugging Tools are added to the recovery image by default, and the path to the Debugging Tools is automatically filled in.
segment.target: If you installed the Microsoft Windows Software Development Kit (SDK) or the Microsoft Windows Development Kit (WDK), the Windows 10 Debugging Tools are added to the recovery image by default, and the path to the Debugging Tools is automatically filled in.

segment.source: You can change the path of the Windows 10 Debugging Tools if the files are located somewhere other than the location indicated by the default file path.
segment.target: You can change the path of the Windows 10 Debugging Tools if the files are located somewhere other than the location indicated by the default file path.

segment.source: A link in the wizard lets you download and install debugging tools for Windows if they are not already installed.
segment.target: A link in the wizard lets you download and install debugging tools for Windows if they are not already installed.

segment.source: To download the Windows Debugging Tools, see Debugging Tools for Windows.
segment.target: To download the Windows Debugging Tools, see Debugging Tools for Windows.

segment.source: Install the Debugging Tools to the default location.
segment.target: Install the Debugging Tools to the default location.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The DaRT wizard checks for the tools in the registry key.
segment.target: The DaRT wizard checks for the tools in the registry key.

segment.source: If the registry value is not there, the wizard looks in one of the following locations, depending on your system architecture:
segment.target: If the registry value is not there, the wizard looks in one of the following locations, depending on your system architecture:

segment.source: To add the debugging tools for Crash Analyzer
segment.target: To add the debugging tools for Crash Analyzer

segment.source: On the Advanced Options page, click the Crash Analyzer tab.
segment.target: On the Advanced Options page, click the Crash Analyzer tab.

segment.source: (Optional) Click Download the Debugging Tools to download the Debugging Tools for Windows.
segment.target: (Optional) Click Download the Debugging Tools to download the Debugging Tools for Windows.

segment.source: Select one of the following options:
segment.target: Select one of the following options:

segment.source: Include the Windows 10 64-bit or 32-bit Debugging Tools.
segment.target: Include the Windows 10 64-bit or 32-bit Debugging Tools.

segment.source: If you select this option, browse to and select the location of the tools if the path is not already displaying.
segment.target: If you select this option, browse to and select the location of the tools if the path is not already displaying.

segment.source: Use the Debugging Tools from the system that is being debugged.
segment.target: Use the Debugging Tools from the system that is being debugged.

segment.source: If you select this option, the Crash Analyzer will not work if the Debugging Tools for Windows are not found on the problem computer.
segment.target: If you select this option, the Crash Analyzer will not work if the Debugging Tools for Windows are not found on the problem computer.

segment.source: Click Next.
segment.target: Click Next.

segment.source: Select the types of recovery image files to create
segment.target: Select the types of recovery image files to create

segment.source: On the Create Image page, you choose an output folder for the recovery image, enter an image name, and select the types of DaRT recovery image files to create.
segment.target: On the Create Image page, you choose an output folder for the recovery image, enter an image name, and select the types of DaRT recovery image files to create.

segment.source: During the recovery image creation process, Windows source files are unpacked, DaRT files are copied to it, and the image is then “re-packed” into the file formats that you select on this page.
segment.target: During the recovery image creation process, Windows source files are unpacked, DaRT files are copied to it, and the image is then “re-packed” into the file formats that you select on this page.

segment.source: The available image file types are:
segment.target: The available image file types are:

segment.source: Windows Imaging File (WIM) - used to deploy DaRT to a preboot execution environment (PXE) or local partition).
segment.target: Windows Imaging File (WIM) - used to deploy DaRT to a preboot execution environment (PXE) or local partition).

segment.source: International Standards Organization (ISO) – used to deploy to CD or DVD, or for use in virtual machines (VM)s).
segment.target: International Standards Organization (ISO) – used to deploy to CD or DVD, or for use in virtual machines (VM)s).

segment.source: The wizard requires that the ISO image have an .iso file name extension because most programs that burn a CD or DVD require that extension.
segment.target: The wizard requires that the ISO image have an .iso file name extension because most programs that burn a CD or DVD require that extension.

segment.source: If you do not specify a different location, the ISO image is created on your desktop with the name DaRT10.ISO.
segment.target: If you do not specify a different location, the ISO image is created on your desktop with the name DaRT10.ISO.

segment.source: PowerShell script – creates a DaRT recovery image with commands that provide essentially the same options that you can select by using the DaRT Recovery Image wizard.
segment.target: PowerShell script – creates a DaRT recovery image with commands that provide essentially the same options that you can select by using the DaRT Recovery Image wizard.

segment.source: The script also enables you to add or changes files in the DaRT recovery image.
segment.target: The script also enables you to add or changes files in the DaRT recovery image.

segment.source: If you select the Edit Image check box on this page, you can customize the recovery image during the image creation process.
segment.target: If you select the Edit Image check box on this page, you can customize the recovery image during the image creation process.

segment.source: For example, you can change the “winpeshl.ini” file to create a custom startup order or to add third-party tools.
segment.target: For example, you can change the “winpeshl.ini” file to create a custom startup order or to add third-party tools.

segment.source: To select the types of recovery image files to create
segment.target: To select the types of recovery image files to create

segment.source: On the Create Image page, click Browse to choose the output folder for the image file.
segment.target: On the Create Image page, click Browse to choose the output folder for the image file.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The size of the image will vary, depending on the tools that you select and the files that you add in the wizard.
segment.target: The size of the image will vary, depending on the tools that you select and the files that you add in the wizard.

segment.source: In the Image name box, enter a name for the DaRT recovery image, or accept the default name, which is DaRT10.
segment.target: In the Image name box, enter a name for the DaRT recovery image, or accept the default name, which is DaRT10.

segment.source: The wizard creates a subfolder in the output path by this name.
segment.target: The wizard creates a subfolder in the output path by this name.

segment.source: Select the types of image files that you want to create.
segment.target: Select the types of image files that you want to create.

segment.source: Choose one of the following:
segment.target: Choose one of the following:

segment.source: To change the files in the recovery image before you create the image files, select the Edit Image check box, and then click Prepare.
segment.target: To change the files in the recovery image before you create the image files, select the Edit Image check box, and then click Prepare.

segment.source: To create the recovery image without changing the files, click Create.
segment.target: To create the recovery image without changing the files, click Create.

segment.source: Click Next.
segment.target: Click Next.

segment.source: Edit the recovery image files
segment.target: Edit the recovery image files

segment.source: You can edit the recovery image only if you selected the Edit Image check box on the Create Image page.
segment.target: You can edit the recovery image only if you selected the Edit Image check box on the Create Image page.

segment.source: After the recovery image has been prepared for editing, you can add and modify the recovery image files before creating the bootable media.
segment.target: After the recovery image has been prepared for editing, you can add and modify the recovery image files before creating the bootable media.

segment.source: For example, you can create a custom order for startup, add various third-party tools, and so on.
segment.target: For example, you can create a custom order for startup, add various third-party tools, and so on.

segment.source: To edit the recovery image files
segment.target: To edit the recovery image files

segment.source: On the Edit Image page, click Open in Windows Explorer.
segment.target: On the Edit Image page, click Open in Windows Explorer.

segment.source: Create a subfolder in the folder that is listed in the dialog box.
segment.target: Create a subfolder in the folder that is listed in the dialog box.

segment.source: Copy the files that you want to the new subfolder, or remove files that you don’t want.
segment.target: Copy the files that you want to the new subfolder, or remove files that you don’t want.

segment.source: Click Create to start creating the recovery image.
segment.target: Click Create to start creating the recovery image.

segment.source: Generate the recovery image files
segment.target: Generate the recovery image files

segment.source: On the Generate Files page, the DaRT recovery image is generated for the file types that you selected on the Create Image page.
segment.target: On the Generate Files page, the DaRT recovery image is generated for the file types that you selected on the Create Image page.

segment.source: To generate the recovery image files
segment.target: To generate the recovery image files

segment.source: On the Generate Files page, click Next to generate the recovery image files.
segment.target: On the Generate Files page, click Next to generate the recovery image files.

segment.source: Copy the recovery image to a CD, DVD, or USB
segment.target: Copy the recovery image to a CD, DVD, or USB

segment.source: On the Create Bootable Media page, you can optionally copy the image file to a CD, DVD, or USB flash drive (UFD).
segment.target: On the Create Bootable Media page, you can optionally copy the image file to a CD, DVD, or USB flash drive (UFD).

segment.source: You can also create additional bootable media from this page by restarting the wizard.
segment.target: You can also create additional bootable media from this page by restarting the wizard.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The Preboot execution environment (PXE) and local image deployment are not supported natively by this tool since they require additional enterprise tools, such as System Center Configuration Manager server and Microsoft Development Toolkit.
segment.target: The Preboot execution environment (PXE) and local image deployment are not supported natively by this tool since they require additional enterprise tools, such as System Center Configuration Manager server and Microsoft Development Toolkit.

segment.source: To copy the recovery image to a CD, DVD, or USB
segment.target: To copy the recovery image to a CD, DVD, or USB

segment.source: On the Create Bootable Media page, select the iso file that you want to copy.
segment.target: On the Create Bootable Media page, select the iso file that you want to copy.

segment.source: Insert a CD, DVD, or USB, and then select the drive.
segment.target: Insert a CD, DVD, or USB, and then select the drive.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: If a drive is not recognized and you install a new drive, you can click Refresh to force the wizard to update the list of available drives.
segment.target: If a drive is not recognized and you install a new drive, you can click Refresh to force the wizard to update the list of available drives.

segment.source: Click the Create Bootable Media button.
segment.target: Click the Create Bootable Media button.

segment.source: To create another recovery image, click Restart, or click Close if you have finished creating all of the media that you want.
segment.target: To create another recovery image, click Restart, or click Close if you have finished creating all of the media that you want.

segment.source: Related topics
segment.target: Related topics

segment.source: Overview of the Tools in DaRT 10
segment.target: Overview of the Tools in DaRT 10

segment.source: Deploying DaRT 10
segment.target: Deploying DaRT 10
